Award.AwardTitle: Large-Scale Fabrication of Multi-Nanopillar Transistors for Energy-Efficient Electronics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
A technology that enables substantial reduction of energy consumption in the operation of electronic devices would promise numerous commercial, military and space applications. For example, ten-fold reduction of energy consumption for smart phones, laptops and tablets could result in ten-fold reduction in frequency of battery recharging. However, obtaining such reductions in device energy consumption has been challenging due to limitations of the transistor architecture that current electronic devices commonly use. This award will investigate a new transistor technology in which the transistor components are made within a single nanoscale pillar and whose operating principle allows electrons to flow with very little energy consumption. A successful execution of this project will enable significant reductions in energy consumption by electronic systems at home, office, store, airport, etc., which will benefit the U.S. economy, environment and society, in general. Various military benefits are also expected, such as, lightweight, more energy-efficient electronic equipment that soldiers carry in their missions, increasing their combat capabilities, enhancing the security of our nation at home and abroad.

A large amount of energy consumption or heat dissipation in the large-scale integrated circuits of modern electronic devices is a critical problem that inhibits the advancement of electronic device technology. Its root cause is the thermal excitation of electrons, which imposes limitations on enabling steep ON/OFF switching, resulting in a large amount of energy consumption. This project investigates a new transistor in which the electron thermal excitation is effectively suppressed so that steep ON/OFF switching capability can be obtained at room temperature, leading to substantial reduction of energy consumption in the transistor operation. The transistors will be constructed as single nanopillars, with each nanopillar containing all the transistor components, such as source, quantum well, tunneling barrier, semiconductor island and drain. A discrete state in the quantum well will serve as an energy filter, which blocks the transport of energetic electrons and effectively suppresses the electron thermal excitation. Importantly, the nanopillar transistors will be fabricated on a large scale combining CMOS-compatible parallel processes and bottom-up assembly of nanoparticles that utilizes self-limiting electrostatic nanoparticle placement technique, where the nanoparticles are used as etch hard masks for producing individually addressable nanopillars.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This project has investigated a new type of transistor that can operate with little energy consumption. The high energy consumption or high heat dissipation of current mainstream transistors originate from the fact that electrons are thermally excited to higher energy states even at room temperature. This project has performed fundamental investigations to filter out this electron thermal excitation and fabricate a new type of transistor in which transport of thermally excited electrons is blocked. A quantum well state has been used to filter out the high energy electrons, where the electron energy filter resides in a vertically arranged stack of films composed of electrode, quantum well, and tunneling barriers. The transistors in which the energy filters are implemented have been fabricated and their transistor operation, i.e., modulations of the electrical currents by gate voltages, has been successfully demonstrated. The vertical configuration of the electron energy filter also allows building the transistors in nanoscale pillars and the procedures to fabricate them have been developed. The procedures include placing nanoparticles on a stack of material layers and vertically etching the material layers using the nanoparticles as etch hardmasks, producing the nanopillars. Importantly, the fabrications of the vertically configured energy filtering structures have been carried out on a large scale, which can also serve as a robust experimental platform to investigate electron energy filtering and other related electron transport phenomena in various material systems.    

Broader Impacts

The future of our economy and the security of our nation will depend on quality work forces in science and engineering fields. It would therefore be very important to raise well-trained and creative next generation scientists and engineers. Drawing the attention of next generation work forces to science and engineering would be most effective when they are exposed to science and engineering at early ages as possible. Considering the above, summer science camps, Materials Camp for Kids, have been offered during the summers. Very young children, elementary school students in the 4th and 5th grades, were recruited to the camps. The camps have provided hands-on experimental modules so that children could experience a flavor of scientific world in real laboratory settings. A unique feature of the Materials Camp for Kids is that children have been given rare opportunities to operate cutting-edge equipment such as scanning electron microscope. Although the operations were assisted by graduate students and their operations were limited to very simple functions, these exposures to real-world scientific equipment at young ages have been intended to leave their minds a memorable moment that could potentially draw their interest to science and engineering in coming years. Healthy and diversified workforce would be an important element for global leadership in science and engineering. The summer camps were designed to promote the diversity in the STEM fields. Children have been recruited from diverse school districts in Dallas/Fort Worth metropolitan area and surrounding cities. In addition, children with nearly equal proportion of genders (~50% of boys and ~50% of girls) have been invited to the camps. Recruiting diversified groups of children to the summer science camps and their exposure to science and engineering from early ages have contributed to attracting the young generation to STEM fields as well as building healthy and diversified society.
